title: 114_hr5922
content: The Act titled "Saving Federal Dollars Through Better Use of Government Purchase and Travel Cards Act of 2016" defines terms like "improper payment" and "questionable transaction" to address issues related to government spending. It also introduces the concept of "strategic sourcing" to improve purchasing efficiency. The Act "Saving Federal Dollars Through Better Use of Government Purchase and Travel Cards Act of 2016" mandates the development of a strategy to expand data analytics for managing government purchase and travel charge card programs. This includes identifying questionable transactions, recovering improper payments, streamlining administrative processes, and developing metrics for purchase and travel card use. The Act mandates the development of purchase and travel card metrics and benchmarks for high-risk activities, as well as a plan to create a library of analytics tools for Federal agencies to use. SEC. 4. GUIDANCE ON IMPROVING INFORMATION SHARING TO CURB IMPROPER PAYMENTS. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget, in consultation with relevant agencies, will issue guidance to improve information sharing among government agencies to identify high-risk activities, review reports on questionable transactions, and facilitate the sharing of information. The Director will issue guidance for sharing information on questionable transactions, fraud schemes, and high-risk activities among government agencies, including additional requirements as needed. SEC. 5. INTERAGENCY CHARGE CARD DATA MANAGEMENT GROUP. Establishment of a purchase and travel charge card data management group by the Administrator of General Services and the Director of the Office of Management and Budget to develop best practices for charge card-issuing banks, review agency transaction data, and identify payment opportunities. The group will meet regularly for three years and include relevant agencies. The purchase and travel charge card data management group, established by the Administrator of General Services and the Director of the Office of Management and Budget, will meet regularly for three years. Relevant agencies, as described in the Government Charge Card Abuse Prevention Act of 2012, will be included. SEC. 6. REPORTING REQUIREMENTS. The General Services Administration must submit a report to Congress on the implementation of the Act, including metrics for reducing improper payments and improving card-based payment utilization. Federal agencies must also report on their implementation activities, and the Office of Management and Budget will consolidate these reports for Congress. The Administrator of General Services will submit a report to Congress within one year of the Act's enactment, identifying additional savings opportunities for government agencies under the Federal charge card programs. This report may be combined with the one required earlier.
